item.title: Elisa add a quote by Madeleine L'Engle
item.description: "You have to write the book that wants to be written. And if the book will be too difficult for grown-ups, then you write it for children." -- Madeleine L'Engle

item.title: Elisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "Friendship is born at that moment when one man says to another: "What! You too? I thought that no one but myself . . .&#34;" -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Elisa add a quote by Walter M. Miller Jr.
item.description: "You don’t <i>have</i> a soul, Doctor. You <i>are</i> a soul. You <i>have</i> a body, temporarily." -- Walter M. Miller Jr.

item.title: Elisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "No book is really worth reading at the age of ten which is not equally – and often far more – worth reading at the age of fifty and beyond." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Elisa add a quote by George Harrison
item.description: "If you don't know where you're going, any road'll take you there" -- George Harrison

item.title: Elisa add a quote by Heber J. Grant
item.description: "That which we persist in doing becomes easier to do, not that the nature of the thing has changed, but our power to do so is increased." -- Heber J. Grant

item.title: Elisa add a quote by J.K. Rowling
item.description: "Remember, if the time should come when you have to make a choice between what is right and what is easy, remember what happened to a boy who was good, and kind, and brave, because he strayed across the path of Lord Voldemort. Remember Cedric Diggory." -- J.K. Rowling

item.title: Elisa add a quote by J.K. Rowling
item.description: "The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death." -- J.K. Rowling

item.title: Elisa add a quote by Michel Legrand
item.description: "The more I live, the more I learn. The more I learn, the more I realize, the less I know." -- Michel Legrand

item.title: Elisa add a quote by Anne Fadiman
item.description: "My daughter is seven, and some of the other second-grade parents complain that their children don't read for pleasure. When I visit their homes, the children's rooms are crammed with expensive books, but the parent's rooms are empty. Those children do not see their parents reading, as I did every day of my childhood. By contrast, when I walk into an apartment with books on the shelves, books on the bedside tables, books on the floor, and books on the toilet tank, then I know what I would see if I opened the door that says 'PRIVATE--GROWNUPS KEEP OUT': a child sprawled on the bed, reading." -- Anne Fadiman
